content: The Act may be cited as the "Our Nation's Trade, Infrastructure, Mobility, and Efficiency Act of 2007" or the "ON TIME Act of 2007". The growth in international trade, especially containerized trade, is straining the nation's transportation network and contributing to traffic congestion near major U.S. international gateways. Between 2000 and 2005, the value of international trade increased from $2 trillion to $2.6 trillion, with the number of containerized trade shipments rising from 59 million to 81 million 20-foot equivalent units. The value of international trade increased from $2 trillion to $2.6 trillion, with containerized trade shipments rising from 59 million to 81 million 20-foot equivalent units. Existing and potential trade agreements suggest further growth in international trade and freight congestion. The US is a member of the World Trade Organization, has 11 free trade agreements, and is negotiating 4 more. Traffic congestion in United States cities is worsening, leading to Americans wasting billions of hours in traffic and spending billions of dollars on extra fuel costs annually. The US is actively involved in international trade, with multiple free trade agreements in place and negotiations ongoing with various countries and organizations. Traffic congestion in US cities is escalating, resulting in Americans wasting 4.2 billion hours in traffic and buying 2.9 billion extra gallons of fuel annually, costing $78 billion. Over 200 freight bottlenecks cause $8 billion in economic losses and 243 million hours of delay each year. To maintain current transportation conditions, $235 billion was invested in 2006 by all levels of government. To maintain current transportation conditions and traffic levels, government investments of $235 billion in 2006, $304 billion in 2015, and $472 billion in 2030 are required. To improve conditions for economic productivity, investments of $288 billion in 2006, $368 billion in 2015, and $561 billion in 2030 are needed. To enhance the Nation's economic productivity through transportation system improvements, government investments of $288 billion in 2006, $368 billion in 2015, and $561 billion in 2030 are necessary. The Act aims to address transportation investment needs in national trade gateway corridors and reduce freight congestion along trade routes affected by international trade growth. The Act aims to reduce freight congestion along trade corridors affected by international trade growth and enhance the reliability of the freight transportation system to improve the quality of life for U.S. citizens. Establishment and collection of national trade gateway corridor fee. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a national trade gateway corridor fee on imported articles, equal to .075 percent of the article's value or $500, whichever is less. The fee for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors will be assessed and collected by the Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security. The fee will be equal to .075 percent of the article's value or $500, whichever is less, as defined in section 402 of the Tariff Act of 1930. The Secretary of Transportation, with consultation from the Secretary of Homeland Security, will assess and collect a fee for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors. The fee will be deposited into a specific account and will not apply after fiscal year 2017. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with other departments, will establish a national trade gateway corridor fee on exported articles. The fee will not apply after fiscal year 2017. The Secretary of Commerce will issue regulations for a national trade gateway corridor fee on exported articles. The fee will be 0.075% of the article's value or $500, whichever is less. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with Homeland Security and Commerce, will assess and collect a fee for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors. The fee for eligible transportation trade corridor projects will be based on the article's value and deposited into a separate account in the Treasury. The fee will not apply after fiscal year 2017. The National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund is established in the Treasury for depositing fees from eligible transportation trade corridor projects. APPORTIONMENT OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation sets aside 2 percent of the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund for administrative expenses. After this set-aside, the remaining funds are apportioned to State departments for implementing the Act. The Secretary apportions remaining funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund to State departments of transportation as grants for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry based on fees collected in the previous fiscal year. The Secretary apportions funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund to State departments of transportation for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors based on fees collected at Customs ports of entry in the previous fiscal year, with specific allocation for corridors spanning multiple states. The Secretary apportions funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund to State departments of transportation for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors spanning multiple states based on lane miles of Federal-aid highways in each state. The Secretary apportions funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund to State departments of transportation for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors spanning multiple states based on vehicle miles traveled on lanes on Federal-aid highways in each state. The Secretary allocates funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund to State transportation departments for projects in multi-state transportation trade corridors based on vehicle miles traveled on Federal-aid highways. The funds remain available for 6 years after the fiscal year ends. The funds allocated for projects in transportation trade corridors remain available for 6 years after the fiscal year ends. Any unobligated funds after this period will be allocated to other States for eligible projects at the Secretary's discretion. SEC. 5. PROJECT SELECTION AND ELIGIBILITY. The Secretary of Transportation must issue project selection guidelines for State departments of transportation to follow in selecting eligible projects for grants under this Act, including consulting with various stakeholders during the process. The Department of Transportation must consult with stakeholders, adhere to planning processes, develop a transparent selection process, and rate proposed projects for grants under this Act. The Department of Transportation must develop a transparent selection process and rate proposed projects for grants under this Act, clearly identifying the basis for rating projects. The Department of Transportation must develop a transparent selection process and rate proposed projects for grants under this Act, clearly identifying the basis for rating projects. SEC. 6. GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds to a State department for projects in transportation trade corridors. Grants are only for eligible projects meeting construction standards for highways on a Federal-aid system. The Federal share of funding is determined for each project. The Federal share of funding for eligible transportation projects under this Act is 80 percent, with the non-Federal share not allowed to come from other Federal funds. The non-Federal share of the cost for eligible projects funded under this Act cannot come from other Federal funds. Prevailing wage rates apply to projects assisted under this section as they would under chapter 1 of title 23, United States Code. SEC. 7. TRANSPORTATION TRADE CORRIDORS. The Secretary of Transportation, with consultation from the Secretary of Commerce, will establish transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry where fees were collected. These corridors must not exceed 300 miles from the port of entry and may include areas in contiguous states. The Secretary of Transportation may establish transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry, which may include areas in contiguous states and not extend more than 300 miles from the port of entry. Multiple ports of entry in close proximity can be included in a single corridor. The deadline for establishing proposed corridors is 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Transportation can establish transportation trade corridors for multiple ports of entry located close to each other, not extending more than 300 miles from the port of entry. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the Secretary must publish proposed corridor boundaries in the Federal Register. A 45-day comment period will be provided for public input and hearings as deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Secretary of Transportation will establish transportation trade corridors within 300 miles of ports of entry. Within one year of the Act's enactment, the final corridor boundaries will be published in the Federal Register. A 45-day comment period will be provided for public input, and periodic reviews and modifications will be conducted. Within one year of the Act's enactment, the Secretary of Transportation will publish the boundaries of transportation trade corridors in the Federal Register. Periodic reviews and modifications will be conducted annually to ensure a corridor for each Customs port of entry. The Secretary of Transportation may conduct reviews, hearings, and other necessary actions to ensure a transportation trade corridor for each Customs port of entry with appropriate boundaries as required by the Act. The Secretary of Transportation will issue regulations within one year of the Act's enactment to carry out its objectives. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. The National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund is authorized to receive appropriations for fiscal years 2009 through 2018. Authorizations for highway projects under this Act become contractual obligations of the Government. Definitions are provided in Section 10 of the Act. The Act defines an "eligible project" as a project eligible for assistance under title 23, United States Code, and includes construction or improvements to a publicly owned intermodal freight transfer facility. The Act defines an "eligible project" as a project eligible for assistance under title 23, United States Code, including construction or improvements to a publicly owned intermodal freight transfer facility.
